And in this case, this criteria is met. We have not made any exception, so it fits with the usual policy, acquisition policy, of BNP Paribas.
Okay.
Due to the high level of synergy I admit, but it's also something we have to consider when we buy something.

Okay. So I guess it includes synergies, because when I have a look at Findomestic in '07, '08, it contributed less than €70 billion of net income, which mean 25% at 500 million, it's close to 30 times, appears 30 times, which is also quite high.

Put it another way I would say that being in litigation with a subsidiary which was a little bit block in its development, we had to share with the seller. We had to share the synergies, which is something which is a common practice in the market.

Okay. Thank you. Perhaps just another question on migration. You furbished the draft on the new IAS 39, which was particularly interesting, especially giving more details on what kind of asset could be included in mark-to-market value, and particularly the sales of assets in loan receivables could include only capital and interest rates, which could actually perhaps have an impact on stocks and also which are reclassified assets which were not included in this kind of specificities like , where you have a kind of credit protection and so on. Do you think it could have an impact on the reclassification you've done late in '08?

You know we have made relatively low amount of reclassification. I think the question you should ask to the banks with high amount of reclassified assets. The total reclassified assets as far as we are concerned at the end of June are reaching only eight billion and the difference between the fair value and the book value is something like 200 million. So, I think, in our case, it's a question which has no practical consequence. That being said, I think we should take this draft as a draft, and not as something which is being necessarily going to be accepted, as such; and especially, it's somewhat surprising to see that after what we have seen in the crisis, it's a draft change which is increasing the proportion of assets having to be fair valued, which was not exactly what everybody was expecting.

Perhaps just last question, you've probably already given the answer, but on the €20 billion of nominal value of the asset which are in the out portfolio of Fortis, could you just tell us what is noted as the current mark-to-market value?

The current market value; the current market value is, by definition is, well, the market value was, I'd say, on the 12th of May by residual market value – sorry, not fair value you mean; what do you mean exactly?
Yes, the market value, yes.

Well, you know for a lot of those products, there is no market. I think, it's probably the market value is not far from I would say, at the 12th of May, I would say that the market value was not far from our own fair value assessment, which is by definition, but you can calculate from slide 31.
Okay. Thank you very much.

But it doesn't mean – I mean, market value for that portfolio which is made up of structure, which are not traded at all with complete illiquid markets, it doesn't mean anything. The big question for that portfolio now is what is going to be the loss – at the terminal loss and how much is going to be repaid and how much not. And this portfolio again is now run on extinction mode and in the banking books and is not traded at all. It would be impossible anywhere to trade it. So it has to be looked at as a – the relevant question, sorry, is not what the market value is. The right question is, how much is going to be repaid and then the answer may be very different.
And do you have a view--
And much higher.
Our next question comes from Alessandro Roccatti of FPX (sic) (FPK) (118:19). Please go ahead.

Hi. Good evening. It's Alessandro Roccatti from Fox-Pitt, Kelton. Three quick questions from me. The first one is on the FICC revenues. You've given some ideas in terms of margins. I'm just wondering whether you can make some comments on the volumes in FICC in the third quarter. The second question is on Italy. We've seen a very strong performance both in terms of revenues and in terms of cost of risk at BNL, and this is very much in contrast with what we've seen for the other Italian banks. I'm just wondering what is your competitive advantage, and for how many more quarters you can sustain such a stronger performance? And finally, just a quick question on Fortis, whether you can confirm the 750 million restructuring costs, and when you're likely to book these charges, please?

Yes. Well, regarding your first question, I understand that you would like to have some update on the third quarter volume. I'm afraid that we are still keeping quarterly and not weekly results, and so we're going to – I don't think we're going to give details on the – on either July or first week of August figures for fixed income. Regarding the Italian performance, Jean-Laurent?

Yes. Well, BNL is a very nice bank. The problem with the bank that was for let's say 12 to 15 years, they just didn't invested in the domestic part because they were lacking cash flow. We've been injecting hundreds of millions of euros in this bank industry figures. Both in IT products, we are doing cross-selling, servicing customers; so obviously, the bank is expanding in terms of number of customers into retail, but also into corporate. When we bought the bank, for example, I do believe that we were number five or number six in the market for the commercial banking business, most probably today we're number three.

We have start a number of, I would say, not so nice way of earning money from the starting point that is to say, for example, having very strong upfront fees on asset management products or insurance life products. So we stopped this two or three years ago.

Obviously, if you look at other Italian banks, be sure, they are in a position in which for example, for this type of product, there is no new production, and you'll get a very negative effect of five to 6% of the new production you are lacking as compared to the previous year.

And I can give you a number of examples. So the performance is linked to basically to two phenomenons. One is the fact that the bank is expanding and this is normal, we have invested a lot in this bank. And second, from the beginning we have changed quite a little bit, let's put it that way, the way we earn money and revenues from the customer base. So this is also a very positive thing. So, how long are we going to expand? As long as we can. This is the story.

With regard to restructuring charge. Let me again refer to the 1st of December, when we are going to release the industrial plan including a revised estimate of the restructuring charges. We have started expending money – expensing money, sorry, for the restructuring. There are 20 million being booked this quarter in the corporate center of the restructuring charges 440. But this is only the beginning, and yes, you will have both the – I would say, the total amount and the phasing of these expenses at the beginning of December.
Okay.
Our next question comes from Jon Peace of Nomura. Please go ahead.

Yes. Hi. Just two very quick questions, please. The first one, I wondered if I can ask a question about the sustainability of C&IB revenues in a different way. If you include cost at 44% of revenues this quarter and your target is 60. Can I assume that that means that you assume the sustainable run rate of revenues is going to come down to about 2.5 billion? The second question is just on the dividend. Given your plans to repay the French government preference shares as quick as is prudent, should we assume that means that you keep the dividend flat or do you want to pay a progressive dividend at the same time as repaying the government preference shares obviously assuming that your earnings continue to growth? Thanks very much.

Well, I think. I'm not sure I understood your question on CIB revenues. The fact that this quarter, we have a cost/income ratio of 44%. You shouldn't derive any guessing from that figure to what we expect the CIB revenues to be in the third quarter and in the next few quarters. Well, I think that as a – I think, in a quick summary, certainly, the second quarter revenues of CIB are very strong and we will see in the third quarter what they are, that's why there is no -- there is no guessing and it's possible from the cost/income ratio of the third quarter – second quarter to what we expect over third quarter.
Now, regarding the dividend. In terms of the dividend, we never give any guidance on the payout ratio. So I can't really answer a question about the dividends.
Okay. Thanks.
That's all.
And our last question comes from Jean-Pierre Lambert of KBW. Please go ahead.

Yes. Good afternoon. I just wanted to ask – sorry, looking at Fortis, you've taken quite a big adjustment to your loan portfolio, and you still have high provisions around 142 basis points of risk-weighted assets in this – if you know – if you annualize your experience of the first – of the six weeks. So I was wondering, why is it the case that despite the fact that you have written down so much, you still have higher provisions? And how do you see the proficiency evolving because there's a kind of warning in the way you present the slide that this is a significant risk going forward. Are we going to go way above 142 basis points in your view? Thank you very much.

Well, looking at the banking beginning of October together with the Belgium Bank and management of the bank. So, well, we have, I would say, a clear understanding of where the bank stand in terms of cost of risk. We cannot say that's through the purchase. We are covered for years or even quarters to come cost of risk of the bank, this is just not possible. So we did on the 12th of May, what was possible to do, and and for the – whether the bank is evolving if we are looking at the underlying business – away of any exceptional items, I would say that Belgium, Belgium and Luxemburg more or less in the same mood as France bid at French Retail Banking, this is the same type of business.

We should have more or less the same kind of evolution. Maybe one of the weak point is the European business center network that Fortis created five years ago. In these centers, we find two types of customers. One, are from Belgium, Benelux origin well known from the bank and the other part are more local, small and medium companies for which currently the cost of risk is rising. So maybe this part is to be monitored more closely, maybe also the leasing operation compared to the one Group of BNP Paribas is an operation that would cost more because of very quick expansion over the last four, five years. In a qualitative way, this is what we can say about Fortis at this stage and we will comment in a much more detailed way on 1st of December.
Thank you very much.
Okay. So thank you very much. And thank you for your question and for your attending of this conference call. Bye, bye.
